answers.answer: Hi,Your general anxiety level from your talk appears to be high.This could be one of the reasons and important one for your twitching. There are other causes for twitching including BFS.Your symptoms could be suggesting a benign fasciculation syndrome (BFS) which is a diagnosis of exclusion and it is recognized by twitching of various voluntary muscles in the body. The twitching is most common in the eyelids, arms, legs, and feet.In addition to twitching, patients with BFS often experience pain, paraesthesia, generalized fatigue, exercise intolerance and/or muscle cramping. Another common feature is an increase in the patient's level of anxiety, especially health-related anxiety.Other likely causes are motor neuron diseases such as ALS, MS etc must be eliminated before BFS can be assumed.An important diagnostic tool here is the electromyography (EMG). If EMG is reported normal, than a diagnosis of BFS can be made.MS has definitive criteria to diagnose, if satisfied then a definitive diagnosis is made.MRI is diagnostic tool for MS.Have you got any endocrine problem?Did you meet neurologist? If not I think you should consult a neurologist at earliest and decide regarding further course of action.Hope this helps you.Bye.

question: HiI am going nuts!  For almost two and a half years I have experience strange sensations mainly twitching.  This started after my child was born and I felt vibrating/buzzing sensastions in my feet.  I thought it was the underfloor heating i was feeling and didnt worry would you believe.  Then for about a year and a half now I have experienced twitching body wide but mainly in the legs particularly the left leg accompanied by a tight feeling.  This is bothersome when I am sitting still or lying down but I do feel some slight degree of pain at times when I walk/run.  After I have exercised/gardened etc it is very apparent often accompanied by a burning sensation.  I have read these forums and think it is BFS but cant help wondering if it is Ms.  I have been under a lot of stress but am reluctant to go and see a doctor and go though a myriad of tests.  I am 42 years old and was hoping life began at forty!  I have suffered from general anxiety approx ten years when one of my kids was sick ago so dont know if this is connected as I am an anxious person.  would appreciate any input. Should I be worrying?  I should mention that I drink a lot of tea but have done for years.  I dont drink much maybe three four glasses of wine a week.  Until this I believe I was in very good health although in my last pregnancy (my child is now three) I was borderline gestational diabetes.
title: Should I see a doctor
